chapter: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question: Question 1: In patients with infective endocarditis, the vegetations are most commonly present on:
questions.explanation:
The mitral valve is the most common valve affected in infective endocarditis. Infective endocarditis is the infection of the endocardial layer of the heart. It may involve the 
endocardial layer over the heart valves, mural endocardium, or septum. However, it can also 
affect intracardiac devices. 916 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Infection of the arteriovenous shunts and the arterio-arterial shunt is called infective 
endarteritis and not infective endocarditis.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a cardiac manifestation of infective endocarditis?
questions.explanation:
Roth's spots are not the cardiac manifestation of infective endocarditis (IE). They are the 
immunological phenomenon seen in patients with infective endocarditis. Symptoms of infective endocarditis can be broadly divided into cardiac and non-cardiac 
manifestations. Non-cardiac manifestations of infective endocarditis are further divided into 
immunologic and vascular phenomena. • Cardiac manifestations of IE: • Presence of new regurgitant murmurs • Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction • Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae- caused due to the extension of infection beyond 
the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue • Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess. • Embolization of coronary arteries • Non-cardiac manifestations of IE: • Immunological phenomena (mnemonic ROGeR): • Osler's nodes- small, tender, red papules that are present on the distal finger and toe pads. • Roth's spots- white-centered retinal hemorrhages • Immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis • Positivity for rheumatoid factor • Vascular phenomena: 917 
Sold by @itachibot • Janeway lesions- these are faint, red, macular, painless lesions, commonly present on the thenar 
and hypothenar eminences. • Major arterial emboli • Septic pulmonary infarct • Mycotic aneurysm • Intracranial hemorrhages • Conjunctival hemorrhages • Splenic abscess • Cerebral abscess The image below shows Roth spot on the retina.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following is not included in the minor criteria of modified Duke criteria for 
clinical diagnosis of infective endocarditis?

options.c: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion
options.d: Positive echocardiogram not meeting major criteria

questions.explanation:
Positive echocardiogram not meeting major criteria was earlier a minor criterion but is now 
removed.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 4: According to the modified Duke criteria, a single positive blood culture is included in the 
major criteria for which organism?
questions.explanation:
According to modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, single positive 
blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800 is included in the major 
criteria.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 5: A known IV drug abuser is referred to medicine OPD from the de-addiction wing due to 
prolonged fever and new-onset seizures. His fever has been present for 2 weeks and did not 
come down with antibiotics. An early diastolic murmur is heard on auscultation. Multiple 
painless skin lesions are present on the hands. What are these lesions?
questions.explanation:
918 
Sold by @itachibot The above scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. The skin lesions shown in the image 
are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous, or hemorrhagic macular or nodular 
lesions, which are present on the palms or soles. Another skin finding that can be found in patients with infective endocarditis is Osler's nodes. In 
contrast to Janeway lesions, these are small, tender, red papules which are present on the distal 
finger and toe pads.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is true about the vegetations seen in infective endocarditis?

options.a: Present mainly along the lines of closure
options.b: Present on both side of valve leaflets

questions.explanation:
Vegetations of infective endocarditis can extend onto chordae and are: • Large and irregular • Mainly present on valve cusps 919 
Sold by @itachibot • Prone to embolization
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 7: You are asked to collect blood samples for culture from a patient suspected to have infective 
endocarditis by a typical pathogen. Choose the correct statement for the same.

options.a: 3 separate culture sets - two aerobic and one anaerobic
options.b: 3 separate culture sets - two anaerobic and one aerobic
options.d: 2 separate culture sets - one aerobic and one anaerobic

questions.explanation:
Option D. According to the Modified Duke 2023 Criteria for infective endocarditis, when a typical 
organism is suspected, two separate culture sets are required, one aerobic and one anaerobic. If an atypical organism is suspected, three or more separate culture sets are used. According to the new Duke’s criteria, there is no specific timing to draw blood for blood culture.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient develops prosthetic valve endocarditis 2 years after valve replacement surgery. 
Which of the following organism is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Patient developing endocarditis 2 years after prosthetic valve surgery suggests late-onset 
endocarditis. In such cases, the most common causative organism is streptococci.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 9: A 38-year-old patient presented with malaise, fatigue, and rigors for 1 week. Multiple 
puncture sites were present on the forearm along with sclerosed veins. His temperature on 
admission was 38.5 °C. Examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur which was loudest at the 
left sternal edge. Three sets of blood cultures were taken. Which organism is most likely to be 
found in his blood cultures?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. Staphylococcus aureus is most 
likely to be positive in cultures as it is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in IV drug 
abusers. Endocarditis in injection drug users is mostly right-sided and involves the tricuspid valve.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question: Question 10: What is the most common cause of culture-negative infective endocarditis?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of culture-negative infective endocarditis is the prior use of antibiotics. Some proportion of patients with endocarditis have negative blood cultures. The important causes 
are: • Prior antibiotic use (most common cause) • IE due to fastidious organisms or unusual pathogens or fungi such as: • Streptococci (Granulicatella and Abiotrophia species) • HACEK organisms • Coxiella burnetii • Bartonella species • Brucella • Tropheryma whipplei 920 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 11: An 80-year-old woman with a history of moderate aortic stenosis presented with fatigue, 
weight loss, and night sweats for 2 weeks. Blood tests showed the following. 
Echocardiography revealed an intracardiac mass on the mitral valve. Blood cultures showed 
growth of Streptococcus gallolyticus. What additional investigation should be performed?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical features and laboratory investigations are suggestive of infective endocarditis 
caused due to Streptococcus gallolyticus. In this condition, a colonoscopy should be performed. Streptococcus gallolyticus originates from the gastrointestinal tract and is associated with polyps 
and colon cancer. Hence, the presence of this organism in the vegetation of infective endocarditis 
should warrant a gastrointestinal investigation.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 12: Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred over transthoracic echocardiography as initial 
investigation in all of the following patients, except:

options.a: Patient with suspected prosthetic valve endocarditis
options.b: Patient with suspected IE presenting with fever
options.c: Patient with suspected IE with a new onset regurgitant murmur
options.d: Patient with suspected IE who has previous history of IE

questions.explanation:
For a patient with low suspicion of IE, transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) will be done as an 
initial investigation. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is preferred as the initial investigation in all high-risk 
patients and/or in patients where a high clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis (IE) exists. TEE is also preferred over TTE for evaluating: • Vegetations < 2mm in diameter • Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) • Detection of myocardial abscess • Detection of valve perforation • Detection of intracardiac fistulae • Detection of vegetations in a patient with a cardiovascular implantable electronic device (CIED)
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 13: Patients with which of the following conditions have the lowest risk of developing infective 
endocarditis?
questions.explanation:
Atrial septal defect (ASD) is associated with a very low incidence of IE. In ASD, the velocity of the 
shunt blood is low due to the decreased pressure gradient between the two atria. This low velocity 
of the blood does not usually damage the lining endocardium. Unrepaired VSD is the most frequent congenital heart disease lesion associated with IE, followed 
by ventricular outflow tract obstructive lesions, such as with tetralogy of Fallot. Risk factors for infective end

questions.question:
Question 14: 910 
Sold by @itachibot A 50-year-old woman underwent mitral valve replacement for severe MR, 5 years ago. She is 
now posted for an elective colonoscopy, for evaluation of altered bowel habits. What is the 
recommendation regarding antibiotic prophylaxis for this patient?

options.a: Amoxicillin, 2g orally, taken 30 to 60 minutes before the procedure
options.b: Clindamycin 600mg orally, taken 30 minutes before the procedure
options.c: Ampicillin, 2g IM or IV 60 minutes before the procedure

questions.explanation:
Antibiotic prophylaxis is not required in patients undergoing genitourinary or gastrointestinal 
procedures even if they have a high-risk cardiac lesion for developing infecting endocarditis (e.g., 
prosthetic valve). Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for patients who are undergoing dental procedures, 
invasive respiratory tract procedures, and procedures on the infected skin.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 15: Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for each of the following patients undergoing dental 
procedures, except:

options.a: A patient with palliative shunt for cyanotic CHD
options.b: A patient with previous CABG surgery
options.c: Patient with valvulopathy post cardiac transplantation
options.d: A patient with prosthetic heart valve

questions.explanation:
Routine antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis is not recommended for patients with 
previous coronary artery bypass graft surgery. They do not have a long-term risk of infection. High-risk cardiac lesions, for which endocarditis prophylaxis is advised before dental procedures 
are: • Prosthetic heart valves • Prior endocarditis • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits • Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the 6 months after repair • Incompletely repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects adjacent to prosthetic 
material • Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation Antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely recommended for patients with acquired valvular heart 
diseases. Standard regimen: Amoxicillin 2g per orally is given 1-hour prior to surgery. In patients with 
penicillin allergy, clarithromycin, and azithromycin 500mg per orally can be given.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 17: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. 
Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for 
Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management?
questions.explanation:
The first-line agents used in the management of Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC) infections 
are trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole), meropenem, minocycline, and ceftazidime 
(3rd generation cephalosporin). Other options: Option A: Burkholderia species are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides and polymyxins. Option C: Tigecycline is less effective in the case of Burkholderia infections. Option D: Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporins have the same mechanism of action 
and compete for the same binding site. Hence, it is not a rational drug combination. BCC is a group of bacteria known for causing severe respiratory distress and septicemia, 
particularly in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). BCC organisms are also found in ICU patients and 
individuals with chronic granulomatous disease, leading to lung disease. BCC colonization in CF 
patients prior to lung transplantation increases the risk of death during the early transplant 
period.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question: Question 18: What is the causative organism of acute rheumatic fever?
questions.explanation:
Acute rheumatic fever is caused due to infection with group A streptococcus (GAS), which is 
Streptococcus pyogenes. It usually follows a streptococcal sore throat or scarlet fever. Other 
groups of streptococci do not cause acute rheumatic fever. 923 
Sold by @itachibot The pathogenesis of the development of ARF is based on the concept of molecular mimicry. The 
antibodies which are produced against M protein and N-acetyl glucosamine of group A 
streptococci, bind to and damage the human endothelial cells. It mainly affects children between 5-14 years of age. Patients have various rheumatologic, cardiac, 
and neurological manifestations. Modified Jone's criteria is used for the diagnosis of acute 
rheumatic fever. The main aim of treatment of rheumatic fever is to relieve symptoms, prevent inflammation and 
prevent further infections by group A streptoccus by the use of penicillins.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question: Question 19: What is the most common clinical feature seen in patients with acute rheumatic fever?
questions.explanation: The most common clinical feature of acute rheumatic fever is carditis followed by polyarthritis.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is a feature of Sydenham’s chorea?

options.b: Affects mainly the head and upper limbs
options.c: Occurs within 3 weeks of streptococcal infection
options.d: Only restricted to one half of the body

questions.explanation:
Choreiform movements in Sydenham’s chorea is mainly seen in the head & upper limbs. Sydenham chorea is characterized by the presence of involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements 
of the hands, arms, shoulders, feet, legs, face, and trunk. The movements may be generalized or 
restricted to one side of the body. It follows a long latent period (more than 6 months) and therefore can occur alone without any 
other clinical manifestations.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following is a feature of subcutaneous nodules palpated in a patient with acute 
rheumatic fever?
questions.explanation:
Subcutaneous nodules are commonly present in hands, feet, elbows, and occiput. 924 
Sold by @itachibot They are firm, painless, and freely movable subcutaneous nodules, present over the bony 
prominences of hands, feet, elbow, and occiput. They are a delayed manifestation of rheumatic 
fever and are usually associated with carditis.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following is a minor criterion according to modified Jones criteria for diagnosis 
of rheumatic fever in low risk population?
questions.explanation:
ESR 60 mm and polyarthralgia are a part of minor criteria for the low-risk population among the 
given options. The major and minor criteria for arthritis differ in low risk and medium to high-risk populations. • For low-risk populations, polyarthritis is a major criterion and polyarthralgia is a minor 
criterion. • In the medium to high-risk populations, polyarthritis, polyarthralgia, monoarthritis are major 
criteria and monoarthralgia is a minor criterion.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 23: Which among the following is not a feature of joint pain seen in patients with rheumatic 
fever?
questions.explanation: In rheumatic fever, joint pain is usually asymmetric. Characteristic features of arthritis of acute rheumatic fever are: • Migratory- the pain moves from one joint to another over a period of hours • Involvement of large joints – most commonly knees, ankle, hips & elbows • Asymmetric • Highly responsive to salicylates
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 24: A 30-year-old patient presented to the clinic with skin lesions as shown in the image. On 
examination, body temperature is 38.5 °C, ESR and ASLO titers are elevated. What is true 
about the skin finding? 913 
Sold by @itachibot

options.d: Generally occurs in patients with carditis

questions.explanation:
The above clinical features are suggestive of rheumatic fever and the skin finding shown in the 
image is erythema marginatum. It generally occurs in patients with carditis. Erythema marginatum is a pink, non-pruritic rash that generally occurs on the upper part of the 
arms or trunk but not on the face. It extends from the centre with an irregular serpiginous border. 
As the size of the rash increases, the center of the rash returns to normal, while the borders 
remain pink. Hence it is named erythema marginatum. The rash may also become more prominent after a hot shower.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 25: Evidence of preceding streptococcal infection is not essential for making a diagnosis of acute 
rheumatic fever in patients presenting with:
questions.explanation:
Evidence of preceding streptococcal infection for making diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) 
is not required in the presence of chorea. 925 
Sold by @itachibot Chorea is frequently a late finding of ARF. When chorea appears, major findings, minor findings 
and findings of preceding streptococcal infection would have been disappeared.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 26: A patient diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever develops a new-onset murmur. His 
echocardiography is likely to reveal:
questions.explanation:
Characteristic initial valvular manifestation in acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is mitral regurgitation. Damage of the valves leads to mitral regurgitation in the early stages. With repeated episodes of 
rheumatic fever, there is thickening, calcification, and stenosis of the affected valve. Mitral regurgitation is the most common cardiac lesion in ARF, while mitral stenosis is the most 
common lesion in rheumatic heart disease. Other cardiac manifestations of acute rheumatic fever include myocardial inflammation that can 
also affect electrical conduction pathways, leading to P-R interval prolongation (first-degree 
atrioventricular block or rarely higher-level block) and softening of the first heart sound.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question: Question 27: The prevalence of rheumatic valvular heart disease peaks between:
questions.explanation:
The prevalence of rheumatic valvular heart disease peaks between 25-40 years. Acute rheumatic fever is mainly a disease of children and is common between 5–14 years of age 
and rare in a person aged more 30 years. In contrast to this, rheumatic valvular heart disease is 
common between 25-40 years.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question: Question 28: The drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea is:
questions.explanation:
The drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea is sodium valproate. Sydenham's chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements which mainly 
affect the head and upper limbs. In the tongue, it is visible as the characteristic darting 
movements. Medications used to treat Sydenham chorea are: • Mild cases: managed by providing a calm environment • Severe cases: dopamine antagonists like haloperidol, pimozide, or antiepileptic medications like 
sodium valproate (preferred due to no extrapyramidal side effects) and carbamazepine • Since Sydenham chorea is thought to be an immune-mediated disorder, steroids are effective in 
the treatment of severe or refractory cases.
questions.chapter_heading: Infective Endocarditis and Acute rheumatic fever

questions.question:
Question 29: A 12-year-old boy is admitted with fever and polyarthritis. His ESR on admission is 80mm/hr. 
There is no evidence of carditis. A diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever is made and treatment 
is initiated. How long will you put the patient on secondary prophylaxis?
questions.explanation:
926 
Sold by @itachibot This patient has a rheumatic fever without carditis. He should be given prophylaxis till 21 years of 
age as the duration of secondary prophylaxis is 5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is 
longer). Secondary prophylaxis is given for patients with acute rheumatic fever (ARF). These patients are 
at a higher risk of developing a further episode of ARF after a group A streptococcal infection. 
Hence they should receive long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrent infections. The antibiotics that can be given for secondary prophylaxis are: • Benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units) given every 4 weeks (Best antibiotic) • Oral penicillin V (250 mg) given twice daily (less effective than benzathine penicillin G) • Erythromycin (250 mg) twice daily (For patients allergic to penicillin) 927 
Sold by @itachibot Hypertensive Vascular Disease
